paragraphs.title: Display mean CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT grouped by CUST_MARITAL_STATUS in descending order
paragraphs.text:
%sql 
SELECT CUST_MARITAL_STATUS, ROUND(AVG(CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT),2)
FROM SH.CUSTOMERS 
GROUP BY CUST_MARITAL_STATUS 
ORDER BY AVG(CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT) DESC

paragraphs.title: STATS_MODE with dynamic data
paragraphs.text:
%md
Note that STATS_MODE can only work with materialized tables, instead of dynamic data like a view or tables joined together. In that case, we recommend using the max count. For example, in the following paragraph we want to find the mode of the *COUNTRY_NAME*, which is obtained from joining two tables. In this case, it is better to achieve that by taking the max count.

msg.data: Note that STATS_MODE can only work with materialized tables, instead of dynamic data like a view or tables joined together. In that case, we recommend using the max count. For example, in the following paragraph we want to find the mode of the COUNTRY_NAME, which is obtained from joining two tables. In this case, it is better to achieve that by taking the max count.

paragraphs.title: Find mode of COUNTRY_NAME, i.e., country with most customers
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT COUNTRY_NAME,
       RANK
FROM (
    SELECT COUNTRY_NAME,  
           ROW_NUMBER() OVER( ORDER BY COUNT DESC) RANK
    FROM (
        SELECT COUNTRY_NAME, COUNT(*) COUNT
        FROM SH.CUSTOMERS CUST, SH.COUNTRIES CO
        WHERE  CUST.COUNTRY_ID = CO.COUNTRY_ID
        GROUP BY COUNTRY_NAME ) A ) B
WHERE RANK =1

paragraphs.title: Display counts of COUNTRY_NAME to highlight mode visually
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT COUNTRY_NAME, COUNT(*) COUNT
FROM SH.CUSTOMERS CUST, SH.COUNTRIES CO
WHERE  CUST.COUNTRY_ID = CO.COUNTRY_ID
GROUP BY COUNTRY_NAME
ORDER BY COUNT DESC
FETCH FIRST 20 ROWS ONLY

paragraphs.title: Check 1st, 2nd, and 3rd quantile of amount sold - PERCENTILE_CONT resolves ties by interpolation. PERCENTILE_DISC outputs first value when seeing a tie
paragraphs.text:
%sql
SELECT PERCENTILE_CONT(0.25) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY AMOUNT_SOLD) 
      "First Quantile cont",
    PERCENTILE_DISC(0.25) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY AMOUNT_SOLD) 
      "First Quantile  disc",
    PERCENTILE_CONT(0.5) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY AMOUNT_SOLD) 
      "Second Quantile cont",
    PERCENTILE_DISC(0.5) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY AMOUNT_SOLD) 
      "Second Quantile  disc",
    PERCENTILE_CONT(0.75) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY AMOUNT_SOLD) 
      "Third Quantile cont",
    PERCENTILE_DISC(0.75) WITHIN GROUP (ORDER BY AMOUNT_SOLD) 
      "Third Quantile  disc"
FROM SH.SALES

paragraphs.title: Using a t-test
paragraphs.text: %md #### Use the SQL t-test function for performing a t-test in-database using the SH.SALES and SH.CUSTOMERS tables. See more information at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_T_TEST_.html The t-test measures the significance of a difference of means. You use it to compare the means of two groups or the means of one group with a constant. A t-test is any statistical hypothesis test in which the test statistic follows a Student's t distribution under the null hypothesis. It can be used to determine if two sets of data are significantly different from each other, and is most commonly applied when the test statistic would follow a Normal distribution if the value of a scaling term in the test statistic were known. When the scaling term is unknown and is replaced by an estimate based on the data, the test statistic (under certain conditions) follows a Student's t distribution. For more details on the background of t-tests , see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student%27s_t-test `Hint`: P_Values < 0.05 show statistically significantly differences (over 95% confidence) in the amounts purchased by men vs. women `Hint`: NaN is used for display when there are nulls and/or empty

msg.data:
Use the SQL t-test function for performing a t-test in-database using the SH.SALES and SH.CUSTOMERS tables.

See more information at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_T_TEST_.html

The t-test measures the significance of a difference of means. You use it to compare the means of two groups or the means of one group with a constant. A t-test is any statistical hypothesis test in which the test statistic follows a Student's t distribution under the null hypothesis. It can be used to determine if two sets of data are significantly different from each other, and is most commonly applied when the test statistic would follow a Normal distribution if the value of a scaling term in the test statistic were known. When the scaling term is unknown and is replaced by an estimate based on the data, the test statistic (under certain conditions) follows a Student's t distribution.
For more details on the background of t-tests , see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Student%27s_t-test

Hint: P_Values < 0.05 show statistically significantly differences (over 95% confidence) in the amounts purchased by men vs. women
Hint: NaN is used for display when there are nulls and/or empty

paragraphs.title: Compare average amount SOLD_TO_MEN versus average amount SOLD_TO_WOMEN grouped by INCOME_LEVEL - determine if significantly different
paragraphs.text:
%sql 

SELECT SUBSTR(CUST_INCOME_LEVEL,1,22) INCOME_LEVEL,  
       ROUND(AVG(DECODE(CUST_GENDER,'M',AMOUNT_SOLD,NULL)),2) SOLD_TO_MEN,  
	   ROUND(AVG(DECODE(CUST_GENDER,'F',AMOUNT_SOLD,NULL)),2) SOLD_TO_WOMEN,  
	   ROUND(STATS_T_TEST_INDEP(CUST_GENDER, AMOUNT_SOLD, 'STATISTIC','F'),2) T_OBSERVED,  
	   ROUND(STATS_T_TEST_INDEP(CUST_GENDER, AMOUNT_SOLD),2) TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE
FROM SH.CUSTOMERS C, SH.SALES S  
WHERE C.CUST_ID=S.CUST_ID  
GROUP BY CUST_INCOME_LEVEL 
ORDER BY 1

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Compare average amount SOLD_TO_MEN versus average amount SOLD_TO_WOMEN grouped by INCOME_LEVEL - determine if significantly different
paragraphs.text:
%sql 

-- Click the bar chart icon and expand settings. Drag INCOME_LEVEL to Keys, TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE to Values and select Avg. The group is empty. 

SELECT SUBSTR(CUST_INCOME_LEVEL,1,22) INCOME_LEVEL,  
       ROUND(AVG(DECODE(CUST_GENDER,'M',AMOUNT_SOLD,NULL)),2) SOLD_TO_MEN,  
	   ROUND(AVG(DECODE(CUST_GENDER,'F',AMOUNT_SOLD,NULL)),2) SOLD_TO_WOMEN,  
	   ROUND(STATS_T_TEST_INDEP(CUST_GENDER, AMOUNT_SOLD, 'STATISTIC','F'),2) T_OBSERVED,  
	   ROUND(STATS_T_TEST_INDEP(CUST_GENDER, AMOUNT_SOLD),2) TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE
FROM SH.CUSTOMERS C, SH.SALES S  
WHERE C.CUST_ID=S.CUST_ID  
GROUP BY CUST_INCOME_LEVEL  
ORDER BY TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE DESC

paragraphs.title: Using an F-test
paragraphs.text: %md #### Use an F-test to compare whether variances of two groups are significantly different See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_F_TEST.html The F-test tests whether variances of two groups are significantly different. The null hypothesis is that the variances of two groups are the same. The observed value of *F* is the ratio of one variance to the other, so values very different from 1 usually indicate significant differences. If the p value is very small (such as p < 0.05), then we reject the null hypothesis and we say that it is statistically significant (at more than 95% confidence) that the variances of the two groups are different. For more details on the background of F-Tests, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-test In the following example, we compare the credit limit in two gender groups. We use F-test to check if the variances of the two gropus are the same.

msg.data:
Use an F-test to compare whether variances of two groups are significantly different

See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_F_TEST.html

The F-test tests whether variances of two groups are significantly different. The null hypothesis is that the variances of two groups are the same. The observed value of F is the ratio of one variance to the other, so values very different from 1 usually indicate significant differences.
If the p value is very small (such as p < 0.05), then we reject the null hypothesis and we say that it is statistically significant (at more than 95% confidence) that the variances of the two groups are different.

For more details on the background of F-Tests, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-test

In the following example, we compare the credit limit in two gender groups. We use F-test to check if the variances of the two gropus are the same.

paragraphs.title: Compare variances of cust_credit_limit for men and women - determine if variances are significantly different
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT ROUND(VARIANCE(DECODE(CUST_GENDER, 'M', CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT, NULL)),2) VAR_MEN,
       ROUND(VARIANCE(DECODE(CUST_GENDER, 'F', CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT, NULL)),2) VAR_WOMEN,
       ROUND(STATS_F_TEST(CUST_GENDER, CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT, 'STATISTIC', 'F'),2) F_STATISTIC,
       ROUND(STATS_F_TEST(CUST_GENDER, CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT),2) TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE
  FROM SH.CUSTOMERS;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
VAR_MEN	VAR_WOMEN	F_STATISTIC	TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE
12879896.68	13046865.01	1.01	0.31

paragraphs.title: Conclusion for F-test
paragraphs.text:
%md
The p-value is greater than 0.05, so the result above shows that the variances of the CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT for men and women has no statistical difference.

msg.data: The p-value is greater than 0.05, so the result above shows that the variances of the CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT for men and women has no statistical difference.

paragraphs.title: Using one way ANOVA test
paragraphs.text: %md #### Using one way ANOVA (analysis of variance) test to verify differences in means (for groups or variables) for statistical significance See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_ONE_WAY_ANOVA.html The one-way analysis of variance function (STATS_ONE_WAY_ANOVA) tests differences in means (for groups or variables) for statistical significance by comparing two different estimates of variance. One estimate is based on the variances within each group or category. This is known as the mean squares within or mean square error. The other estimate is based on the variances among the means of the groups. This is known as the mean squares between. If the means of the groups are significantly different, then the mean squares between will be larger than expected and will not match the mean squares within. If the mean squares of the groups are consistent, then the two variance estimates will be about the same. For more information and background on ANOVA, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-way_analysis_of_variance In the following example, we apply the one way ANOVA to test for each gender, whether the amount sold varies according to the income level.

msg.data:
Using one way ANOVA (analysis of variance) test to verify differences in means (for groups or variables) for statistical significance

See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_ONE_WAY_ANOVA.html

The one-way analysis of variance function (STATS_ONE_WAY_ANOVA) tests differences in means (for groups or variables) for statistical significance by comparing two different estimates of variance. One estimate is based on the variances within each group or category. This is known as the mean squares within or mean square error. The other estimate is based on the variances among the means of the groups. This is known as the mean squares between. If the means of the groups are significantly different, then the mean squares between will be larger than expected and will not match the mean squares within. If the mean squares of the groups are consistent, then the two variance estimates will be about the same.

For more information and background on ANOVA, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-way_analysis_of_variance

In the following example, we apply the one way ANOVA to test for each gender, whether the amount sold varies according to the income level.

paragraphs.title: Apply one way ANOVA test to different income levels and the amount sold, for each gender group.
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT CUST_GENDER,
       ROUND(STATS_ONE_WAY_ANOVA(CUST_INCOME_LEVEL, AMOUNT_SOLD, 'MEAN_SQUARES_BETWEEN'),2) MEAN_SQUARES_BETWEEN ,
       ROUND(STATS_ONE_WAY_ANOVA(CUST_INCOME_LEVEL, AMOUNT_SOLD, 'MEAN_SQUARES_WITHIN'),2) MEAN_SQUARES_WITHIN,
       STATS_ONE_WAY_ANOVA(CUST_INCOME_LEVEL, AMOUNT_SOLD, 'SIG') P_VALUE
  FROM SH.CUSTOMERS C, SH.SALES S
  WHERE C.CUST_ID = S.CUST_ID
  GROUP BY CUST_GENDER;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: Conclusion of one way ANOVA test
paragraphs.text:
%md
From ANOVA test result, we can see that for each gender group, the mean value of the amount sold is significantly different across income levels.

msg.data: From ANOVA test result, we can see that for each gender group, the mean value of the amount sold is significantly different across income levels.

paragraphs.title: Prepare a view that consists of the gender and the amount sold
paragraphs.text:
%sql

CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW CUST_GENDER_AMOUNT_SOLD_V AS
SELECT CUST_GENDER, AMOUNT_SOLD
  FROM SH.CUSTOMERS C, SH.SALES S
  WHERE C.CUST_ID = S.CUST_ID

paragraphs.title: Using Kolmogorov-Smirnov test
paragraphs.text: %md --- #### Use a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to compare whether two samples come from the same population See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_KS_TEST.html Kolmogorov-Smirnov test compares two samples to test whether they are from the same population or from populations that have the same distribution. It does not assume that the population from which the samples were taken is normally distributed. The null hypothesis is that the two groups of data come from the same population or distribution. If the p-value < 0.05, then we reject the null hypothesis and determine that the two groups of data come from the different populations with more than 95% confidence. For more details and background on K-S tests, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov%E2%80%93Smirnov_test In the following example, we check whether the distributions of the amount sold by two gender groups is different in distribution with statistical significance.

msg.data:
Use a Kolmogorov-Smirnov test to compare whether two samples come from the same population

See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_KS_TEST.html

Kolmogorov-Smirnov test compares two samples to test whether they are from the same population or from populations that have the same distribution. It does not assume that the population from which the samples were taken is normally distributed. The null hypothesis is that the two groups of data come from the same population or distribution. If the p-value < 0.05, then we reject the null hypothesis and determine that the two groups of data come from the different populations with more than 95% confidence.

For more details and background on K-S tests, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kolmogorov%E2%80%93Smirnov_test

In the following example, we check whether the distributions of the amount sold by two gender groups is different in distribution with statistical significance.

paragraphs.title: Kolmogorov-Smirnov test - determine if distributions of amount sold by two gender groups are statistically different
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT ROUND(STATS_KS_TEST(CUST_GENDER, AMOUNT_SOLD, 'STATISTIC'),5) KS_STATISTIC,
       ROUND(STATS_KS_TEST(CUST_GENDER, AMOUNT_SOLD),5) P_VALUE
  FROM CUST_GENDER_AMOUNT_SOLD_V

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
KS_STATISTIC	P_VALUE
0.00384	0.00408

paragraphs.title: Conclusion of   Kolmogorov-Smirnov test
paragraphs.text:
%md

---
Since the p-value < 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis that the distributions of two gender groups are the same. Kolmogorov-Smirnov test result shows that the difference of distributions of two gender groups is significant at the more than 95% confidence.

msg.data: Since the p-value < 0.05, we reject the null hypothesis that the distributions of two gender groups are the same. Kolmogorov-Smirnov test result shows that the difference of distributions of two gender groups is significant at the more than 95% confidence.

paragraphs.title: Using Mann Whitney test
paragraphs.text: %md --- #### Use a Mann Whitney test to check whether two populations have the same distribution function See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_MW_TEST.html For more details and background on the Mann Whitney test, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mann%E2%80%93Whitney_U_test It compares two independent samples to test the null hypothesis that two populations have the same distribution function against the alternative hypothesis that the two distribution functions are different.

msg.data:
Use a Mann Whitney test to check whether two populations have the same distribution function

See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_MW_TEST.html

For more details and background on the Mann Whitney test, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mann%E2%80%93Whitney_U_test

It compares two independent samples to test the null hypothesis that two populations have the same distribution function against the alternative hypothesis that the two distribution functions are different.

paragraphs.title: Mann Whitney Test - determine if distributions of amount sold by two gender groups are statistically different
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT ROUND(STATS_MW_TEST(CUST_GENDER, CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT, 'STATISTIC'),2) Z_STATISTIC,
       ROUND(STATS_MW_TEST(CUST_GENDER, CUST_CREDIT_LIMIT, 'TWO_SIDED_SIG', 'F'),2) TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE
  FROM SH.CUSTOMERS C, SH.SALES S
  WHERE C.CUST_ID = S.CUST_ID;

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
Z_STATISTIC	TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE
-0.78	0.43

paragraphs.title: Conclusion of Mann Whitney Test
paragraphs.text:
%md

---
Since the p-value is much larger than 0.05, we do not reject the hypothesis that the distributions of the amount sold in the two groups is the same. This means that the difference observed from the data is not significant.

msg.data: Since the p-value is much larger than 0.05, we do not reject the hypothesis that the distributions of the amount sold in the two groups is the same. This means that the difference observed from the data is not significant.

paragraphs.title: Create a view that contains income level and the amount sold to men and women
paragraphs.text:
%sql

CREATE OR REPLACE VIEW INCOME_GENDER_SOLD_V AS
SELECT SUBSTR(CUST_INCOME_LEVEL,1,22) INCOME_LEVEL,  
	ROUND(AVG(DECODE(CUST_GENDER,'M',AMOUNT_SOLD,NULL)),2) SOLD_TO_MEN,  
	ROUND(AVG(DECODE(CUST_GENDER,'F',AMOUNT_SOLD,NULL)),2) SOLD_TO_WOMEN
    FROM SH.CUSTOMERS C, SH.SALES S  
    WHERE C.CUST_ID=S.CUST_ID  
    AND SUBSTR(CUST_INCOME_LEVEL,1,22) IS NOT NULL
    GROUP BY CUST_INCOME_LEVEL

paragraphs.title: Display the view
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT * 
FROM INCOME_GENDER_SOLD_V

paragraphs.title: Using Wilcoxon Signed Rank Test
paragraphs.text: %md --- #### Use Wilcoxon Signed Rank test to determine whether the median of the differences between the samples are the same See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_WSR_TEST.html Wilcoxon Signed Ranks test of paired samples to determine whether the median of the differences between the samples is significantly different from zero. The absolute values of the differences are ordered and assigned ranks. Then the null hypothesis states that the sum of the ranks of the positive differences is equal to the sum of the ranks of the negative differences. For more information and background on Wilcoxon Signed Rank tests, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilcoxon_signed-rank_test In the following example, we go through each income level and obtain average amount sold to each gender group. We are interested to know whether there is a difference between the amount sold to men or women for each income level. WSR test focuses on the median of the differences of the amount sold in the two gender groups and do a hypothesis testing on whether the median is significantly different. The null hypothesis is that the median is the same.

msg.data:
Use Wilcoxon Signed Rank test to determine whether the median of the differences between the samples are the same

See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/STATS_WSR_TEST.html

Wilcoxon Signed Ranks test of paired samples to determine whether the median of the differences between the samples is significantly different from zero. The absolute values of the differences are ordered and assigned ranks. Then the null hypothesis states that the sum of the ranks of the positive differences is equal to the sum of the ranks of the negative differences.

For more information and background on Wilcoxon Signed Rank tests, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilcoxon_signed-rank_test

In the following example, we go through each income level and obtain average amount sold to each gender group. We are interested to know whether there is a difference between the amount sold to men or women for each income level. WSR test focuses on the median of the differences of the amount sold in the two gender groups and do a hypothesis testing on whether the median is significantly different. The null hypothesis is that the median is the same.

paragraphs.title: Wilcoxon Signed Ranks Test - determine if median of difference between amount sold to men and amount sold to women is statistically different from zero
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT ROUND(STATS_WSR_TEST(SOLD_TO_MEN, SOLD_TO_WOMEN, 'STATISTIC'),2) Z_STATISTIC,
       ROUND(STATS_WSR_TEST(SOLD_TO_MEN, SOLD_TO_WOMEN, 'TWO_SIDED_SIG'),2) TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE
  FROM INCOME_GENDER_SOLD_V

msg.data:
Z_STATISTIC	TWO_SIDED_P_VALUE
-0.12	0.91

paragraphs.title: Conclusion of Wilcoxon Signed Rank Test
paragraphs.text:
%md

---
The p-value is much greater than 0.05. We do not reject the null hypothesis. This means that the difference between the median of the amount sold to two gender groups is not significant.

msg.data: The p-value is much greater than 0.05. We do not reject the null hypothesis. This means that the difference between the median of the amount sold to two gender groups is not significant.

paragraphs.title: Using Pearson's correlation
paragraphs.text: %md --- #### Using Pearson's correlation coefficient to measure the correlation between two columns See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/CORR.html This is most popular correlation coefficient and widely used for measuring correlation of a set of number pairs. For more information and background on Pearson's correlation, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearson_correlation_coefficient

msg.data:
Using Pearson's correlation coefficient to measure the correlation between two columns

See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/CORR.html

This is most popular correlation coefficient and widely used for measuring correlation of a set of number pairs.
For more information and background on Pearson's correlation, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearson_correlation_coefficient

paragraphs.title: Compute Pearson's correlation between amount sold to the two gender groups
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT ROUND(CORR(SOLD_TO_MEN, SOLD_TO_WOMEN),2) CORRELATION_COEF
FROM INCOME_GENDER_SOLD_V

paragraphs.title: Using Spearman's rho correlation coefficient
paragraphs.text: %md --- #### Using Spearman's rho correlation coefficient to measure the correlation between two columns See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/CORR_A.html Spearman's rho correlation coefficient can find the nonlinear relationship between two variables by focusing the rank of each variables. The Spearman's rho correlation also provides a significance indicator like the p-value. If p-value is small (< 0.05), then it means that there are significant corrleation between the two groups. For more details and background on Spearman's rho correlation, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spearman%27s_rank_correlation_coefficient In the following example, we compute Spearman's rho coefficient between the income level and the amount sold to men and women. We check if the correlation between the amount sold and their income level is significant for men and women.

msg.data:
Using Spearman's rho correlation coefficient to measure the correlation between two columns

See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/CORR_A.html

Spearman's rho correlation coefficient can find the nonlinear relationship between two variables by focusing the rank of each variables. The Spearman's rho correlation also provides a significance indicator like the p-value. If p-value is small (< 0.05), then it means that there are significant corrleation between the two groups.

For more details and background on Spearman's rho correlation, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spearman%27s_rank_correlation_coefficient
In the following example, we compute Spearman's rho coefficient between the income level and the amount sold to men and women. We check if the correlation between the amount sold and their income level is significant for men and women.

paragraphs.title: Compute Spearman's rho correlation coefficient for income level and the amount sold to men,  income level and the amount sold to women
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT  ROUND(CORR_S(INCOME_LEVEL, SOLD_TO_MEN, 'COEFFICIENT'),2) MEN_COEFFICIENT,  
        ROUND(CORR_S(INCOME_LEVEL, SOLD_TO_MEN, 'TWO_SIDED_SIG'),2) MEN_TWO_SIDED_SIG,
        ROUND(CORR_S(INCOME_LEVEL, SOLD_TO_WOMEN, 'COEFFICIENT'),2) WOMEN_COEFFICIENT,  
        ROUND(CORR_S(INCOME_LEVEL, SOLD_TO_WOMEN, 'TWO_SIDED_SIG'),2) WOMEN_TWO_SIDED_SIG
FROM  INCOME_GENDER_SOLD_V

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

msg.data:
MEN_COEFFICIENT	MEN_TWO_SIDED_SIG	WOMEN_COEFFICIENT	WOMEN_TWO_SIDED_SIG
0.71	0.01	0.38	0.22

paragraphs.title: Conclusion of Spearman's rho correlation
paragraphs.text:
%md

---
For the correlation between the income level and the amount sold to men, the TWO_SIDED_SIG value is very small, which indicates the correlation between the income level and the amount sold to men has significant correlation. But for women, such a relationship is not significant.

msg.data: For the correlation between the income level and the amount sold to men, the TWO_SIDED_SIG value is very small, which indicates the correlation between the income level and the amount sold to men has significant correlation. But for women, such a relationship is not significant.

paragraphs.title: Using Kendall's tau-b correlation
paragraphs.text: %md --- #### Using Kendall's tau-b correlation to measure the correlation between two columns See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/CORR_A.html Kendall's tau-b correlation coefficient also reveals the nonlinear relationship between two variables. To calculate the coefficient, the number of concordant and discordant pairs is computed. A pair of observations is concordant if the observation with the larger x also has a larger value of y. A pair of observations is discordant if the observation with the larger x has a smaller y. The Kendall's tau-b also provides a significance indicator like the p-value. If p-value is small (< 0.05), then it means that there are significant corrleation between the two groups. For more details and background on Kendall's tau-b correlation, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kendall_rank_correlation_coefficient In the following example, we compute Kendall's tau-b coefficient between the income level and the amount sold to men and women. We check if the correlation between the amount sold and their income level is significant for men and women.

msg.data:
Using Kendall's tau-b correlation to measure the correlation between two columns

See documentation at https://docs.oracle.com/en/database/oracle/oracle-database/21/sqlrf/CORR_A.html

Kendall's tau-b correlation coefficient also reveals the nonlinear relationship between two variables. To calculate the coefficient, the number of concordant and discordant pairs is computed. A pair of observations is concordant if the observation with the larger x also has a larger value of y. A pair of observations is discordant if the observation with the larger x has a smaller y.
The Kendall's tau-b also provides a significance indicator like the p-value. If p-value is small (< 0.05), then it means that there are significant corrleation between the two groups.
For more details and background on Kendall's tau-b correlation, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kendall_rank_correlation_coefficient

In the following example, we compute Kendall's tau-b coefficient between the income level and the amount sold to men and women. We check if the correlation between the amount sold and their income level is significant for men and women.

paragraphs.title: Kendall's tau-b correlation coefficient  for income level and amount sold to men, and income level and amount sold to women
paragraphs.text:
%sql

SELECT ROUND(CORR_K(INCOME_LEVEL, SOLD_TO_MEN, 'COEFFICIENT'),2) MEN_COEFFICIENT,  
       ROUND(CORR_K(INCOME_LEVEL, SOLD_TO_MEN, 'TWO_SIDED_SIG'),2) MEN_TWO_SIDED_SIG,
       ROUND(CORR_K(INCOME_LEVEL, SOLD_TO_WOMEN, 'COEFFICIENT'),2) WOMEN_COEFFICIENT,  
       ROUND(CORR_K(INCOME_LEVEL, SOLD_TO_WOMEN, 'TWO_SIDED_SIG'),2) WOMEN_TWO_SIDED_SIG
FROM  INCOME_GENDER_SOLD_V
